questions.text: Non-traumatic amputation is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ All three conditions (sickle cell disease, diabetes mellitus, and leprosy) can lead to non-traumatic amputations due to complications that affect the blood vessels, nerves, and tissues of the limbs. These complications include ischemia, chronic ulcers, infections, and gangrene, which may necessitate surgical removal of the affected limb or part of the limb to prevent further health deterioration or systemic infection.
  • ➤ All three conditions (sickle cell disease, diabetes mellitus, and leprosy) can lead to non-traumatic amputations due to complications that affect the blood vessels, nerves, and tissues of the limbs.
  • ➤ These complications include ischemia, chronic ulcers, infections, and gangrene, which may necessitate surgical removal of the affected limb or part of the limb to prevent further health deterioration or systemic infection.

questions.text: A small boy brought to the emergency department by his parents is found to have a spiral fracture of the femur, with a variety of ecchymoses. Likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Child abuse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In conclusion, based on the presentation of a spiral fracture of the femur with ecchymoses, the most likely cause in this scenario, Child abuse. This answer is chosen because the mechanism of injury and the associated findings are highly suggestive of non-accidental trauma.
  • ➤ In conclusion, based on the presentation of a spiral fracture of the femur with ecchymoses, the most likely cause in this scenario, Child abuse.
  • ➤ This answer is chosen because the mechanism of injury and the associated findings are highly suggestive of non-accidental trauma.

questions.text: Characteristic subperiosteal bone resorption in Hyperparathyroidism is best seen at:
questions.correct_answer: C. Radial border of middle phalanx
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radial border of middle phalanx

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic subperiosteal bone resorption in hyperparathyroidism is best seen at the radial border of the middle phalanx. This location is chosen because it provides a clear and typical manifestation of the bone changes associated with elevated PTH levels in hyperparathyroidism.
  • ➤ The characteristic subperiosteal bone resorption in hyperparathyroidism is best seen at the radial border of the middle phalanx.
  • ➤ This location is chosen because it provides a clear and typical manifestation of the bone changes associated with elevated PTH levels in hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:

A 38-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of lower back pain. X-ray films of her back show a lordosis of the vertebral column. This increased curvature of the vertebral column is best described by which of the following terms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Convex anteriorly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Therefore, in the context of the patient with lower back pain and X-ray findings showing lordosis of the vertebral column, the increased curvature is best described by the term "convex anteriorly" (option C). This terminology accurately reflects the natural anatomical curvature of the lumbar spine where the vertebral bodies curve inward toward the front of the body.
  • ➤ Therefore, in the context of the patient with lower back pain and X-ray findings showing lordosis of the vertebral column, the increased curvature is best described by the term "convex anteriorly" (option C).
  • ➤ This terminology accurately reflects the natural anatomical curvature of the lumbar spine where the vertebral bodies curve inward toward the front of the body.

questions.text: An old lady presented with long-standing arthritis of both hands and feet. X-ray feature that suggests rheumatoid arthritis rather than seronegative spondyloarthropathies is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Periarticular erosions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In summary, the correct answer to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from seronegative spondyloarthropathies based on X-ray features is B. Periarticular erosions. This feature is characteristic of RA and helps distinguish it from other types of arthritis that may affect the hands and feet.
  • ➤ In summary, the correct answer to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from seronegative spondyloarthropathies based on X-ray features is B. Periarticular erosions.
  • ➤ This feature is characteristic of RA and helps distinguish it from other types of arthritis that may affect the hands and feet.

questions.text: X-ray of Tibia of an adolescent boy is shown. Probable diagnosis is:
Hyperglycemia is associated with:
The fracture of tibia in adults heals within:
Index finger infection spreads to:
The complication of Colles fracture is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stiffness of finger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Option A, stiffness of the finger, is considered a complication of Colles fracture due to the potential for joint stiffness and contracture following immobilization and inadequate rehabilitation. This complication highlights the importance of early mobilization and physical therapy in the management of distal radius fractures to optimize recovery and prevent long-term functional impairment.
  • ➤ Option A, stiffness of the finger, is considered a complication of Colles fracture due to the potential for joint stiffness and contracture following immobilization and inadequate rehabilitation.
  • ➤ This complication highlights the importance of early mobilization and physical therapy in the management of distal radius fractures to optimize recovery and prevent long-term functional impairment.
